intro: Ranunculus major, commonly known as the greater celandine, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy, petal-like sepals and numerous stamens. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with broad, lobed leaves and bright yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its roots are often used in traditional medicine for their anti-inflammatory properties. The plant prefers moist, well-drained soils and can be found in meadows, woodland edges, and along stream banks.
